Subject: Re: [neat] Request for Comments: Geographical and Behavioural Space Considerations
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=KZTqpx31dsYVSehAbdo0F8xap8zCeHhomG2yeFVm4yIOLhDtsy7_

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Colin (and Ken),

I second this feature request. It would be great to=
 have a standard multi-objective (NSGA-II) NEAT package. Neuromodulation wo=
uld also be a very useful thing to have in the toolkit.  


Best regards,
J=
eff Clune

Assistant Professor
Computer Science
University of Wyoming
jeffc=
lune@...
jeffclune.com

On Aug 29, 2013, at 6:42 PM, kstanley@...=
s.edu wrote:

> 
> Hi Colin, it will be interesting to see how the more eme=
rgent geographical-based speciation compares to conventional fitness-sharin=
g-based NEAT speciation.   My guess is that they would yield fairly similar=
 results depending on the particulars of the new approach.  Do you think we=
'd see some significant differences in certain contexts?    
> 
> 
> 
> To =
add another reference to those mentioned by others, Melanie Mitchell did so=
me work in spatially-distributed coevolutionary populations, though I under=
stand you aren't initially aiming for coevolution.  Still, it could provide=
 some inspiration.  It's called "Coevolutionary learning with spatially dis=
tributed populations":
> 
> 
> 
> http://www.cs.pdx.edu/~mm/MitchellWCCI200=
6.pdf
> 
> 
> 
> I have one other random/unrelated suggestion for future Sh=
arpNEAT releases.  Of course I am not meaning to demand something, but just=
 to give you something that may or may not inspire you in the future:  In o=
ur group and others multiobjective optimization is increasingly being used =
in combination with NEAT and neuroevolution.  As mentioned in prior discuss=
ions in this group, if you wrap NEAT with NSGA II (the multiobjective evolu=
tionary algorithm) then you can pretty much get away with substituting a "g=
enetic diversity" objective (which uses historical markings to compute dist=
ances as in regular NEAT) for traditional NEAT-style speciation and get sim=
ilar results to original NEAT.  But the main motivation for having a multio=
bjective framework is you can combine different reward schemes.  For exampl=
e, the novelty search+local competition (NSLC) algorithm from Joel Lehman a=
nd myself makes novelty one objective and local competition another (and ge=
netic diversity a third).  Of course many people on this group have done ot=
her great stuff with multiple objectives.  Anyway, having that ability open=
s up a lot of room to play with ideas, so it would be cool if some future S=
harpNEAT came with a user-friendly framework for specifying a set of multip=
le objectives.  Just daydreaming for the future :)
> 
> 
> 
> In any case, =
thanks so much for the great platform you've provided.
> 
> 
> 
> Best,
> 
=
> 
> 
> ken
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, <colin.green1@...=
> wrote:
> 
> Hi all,
> 
> I'm starting to think about direction for the ne=
xt SharpNEAT
> iteration. There's been a lot of talk recently about novelty=
 search
> versus objective search, and maybe mixtures of the two. I myself
=
> talked about how in the natural world organisms are separated in both
> b=
ehavioural space (i.e. novel behaviour is less likely to compete for
> the =
same resources as existing behaviours) but also geographical
> space, and I=
 think that geographical space is a key factor that is
> missing from NEAT =
based search currently, and possibly EC as a whole,
> with the caveat there=
 may be other research groups with work in that
> area that I'm unaware of.=

> 
> My current plan is to focus on this geographical space idea for this
=
> iteration because it is the simplest to implement. Dealing with
> behavio=
ural space is potentially more complicated because how to
> compare behavio=
ur varies across problem domains and how you identify
> the key factors to =
compare is probably a non-trivial problem. I want
> to try and tackle this =
at some point, but I'm also keen to explore the
> geo-space idea.
> 
> What=
 does this all mean in practical terms?
> 
> SharpNEAT is a kit of parts th=
at allows you to swap in replacement
> parts such as an alternative genetic=
 representation and/or associated
> genetic operators (recombination, mutat=
ion, etc) with minimal impact
> on other parts in the kit (in principle any=
way). I'm proposing to
> provide an alternative evolution algorithm class t=
hat replaces NEAT's
> genome based speciation (which clusters genomes into =
K clusters in
> genetic space), with a geographical space alternative (I'll=
 call it
> geo-space for short).
> 
> The idea is that we have some cartesi=
an/euclidean space (probably a
> square 2D space initially to keep the code=
 simple, but 3D or 'globe'
> space (2-sphere) are reasonable alternatives).=
 The seed genomes are
> each assigned a random coord in the geo-space and t=
his will be fixed
> for the life of that genome. So we are basically adding=
 a physical
> attribute to the genome such that our population members are =
probably
> better referred to as organisms (or agents or population members=
).
> I'll use 'agent' because it's easier to type :)
> 
> Agent fitness is =
now adjusted by population density at the agent's
> geo-location, this allo=
ws really bad agents to survive so long as they
> are in a sparse region of=
 geo-space, thus allowing for some diversity
> of the genome pool.
> 
> Rep=
roduction - I haven't put much thought into this but the two
> options I se=
e are to create offspring agents near to their parent(s)
> versus randomly =
scattered. Probably some 'dispersion' variable will
> define the amount of =
scattering with 0 being atop of the parent (or
> between the two?) and 1 be=
ing totally random. (Question: Is e.g. seed
> scattering in nature gaussian=
?). Clearly if agent's are spawned near
> their parent's we would expect to=
 see clusters of agent's with similar
> behaviour, and that clustering will=
 increase population density and
> therefore lower the fitness of agent's i=
n that cluster. So there is a
> form of fitness sharing going on, but as I =
say, I haven't really
> thought through the implications and dynamics of th=
at. But it would be
> interesting to set up, play with and observe what hap=
pens.
> 
> Factoring in behavioural space considerations should be possible=
 at a
> later date, e.g. fitness at a geo-location is not adjusted down if =
an
> agent has novel behaviour compared to other agent's at that
> geo-loca=
tion.
> 
> As per usual - any thoughts and feedback are welcome.
> 
> Colin=

> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_7F221E2E-EA78-45D4-8030-B7C7AD3CC3FE

    <div id=3D"ygrp-text"><div><br=
 class=3D"webkit-block-placeholder"></div><p>Hi Colin, it will be interesti=
ng to see how the more emergent geographical-based speciation compares to c=
onventional fitness-sharing-based NEAT speciation.   My guess is that =
they would yield fairly similar results depending on the particulars of the=
 new approach.  Do you think we'd see some significant differences in =
certain contexts?    </p><p><br></p><p style=3D"font-size: 1=
3px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; background-color: tr=
ansparent; font-style: normal; ">To add another reference to those mentione=
d by others, Melanie Mitchell did some work in spatially-distributed coevol=
utionary populations, though I understand you aren't initially aiming for c=
oevolution.  Still, it could provide some inspiration.  It's call=
ed "Coevolutionary learning with spatially distributed populations":<br></p=
><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-se=
rif; background-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><br></p><p style=
=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; back=
ground-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><a href=3D"http://www.cs.p=
dx.edu/~mm/MitchellWCCI2006.pdf">http://www.cs.pdx.edu/~mm/MitchellWCCI2006=
.pdf</a></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, cle=
an, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><br></=
p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-s=
erif; background-color: transparent; font-style: normal; ">I have one other=
 random/unrelated suggestion for future SharpNEAT releases.  Of course=
 I am not meaning to demand something, but just to give you something that =
may or may not inspire you in the future:  In our group and others mul=
tiobjective optimization is increasingly being used in combination with NEA=
T and neuroevolution.  As mentioned in prior discussions in this group=
, if you wrap NEAT with NSGA II (the multiobjective evolutionary algorithm)=
 then you can pretty much get away with substituting a "genetic diversity" =
objective (which uses historical markings to compute distances as in regula=
r NEAT) for traditional NEAT-style speciation and get similar results to or=
iginal NEAT.  But the main motivation for having a multiobjective fram=
ework is you can combine different reward schemes.  For example, the n=
ovelty search+local competition (NSLC) algorithm from Joel Lehman and mysel=
f makes novelty one objective and local competition another (and genetic di=
versity a third).  Of course many people on this group have done other=
 great stuff with multiple objectives.  Anyway, having that ability op=
ens up a lot of room to play with ideas, so it would be cool if some future=
 SharpNEAT came with a user-friendly framework for specifying a set of mult=
iple objectives.  Just daydreaming for the future :)</p><p style=3D"fo=
nt-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; background=
-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><br></p><p style=3D"font-size: 1=
3px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; background-color: tr=
ansparent; font-style: normal; ">In any case, thanks so much for the great =
platform you've provided.<br></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: =
arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-st=
yle: normal; "><br></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, hel=
vetica, clean, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-style: norma=
l; ">Best,</p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, c=
lean, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><br>=
</p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans=
-serif; background-color: transparent; font-style: normal; ">ken<br></p><p =
style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif;=
 background-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><br></p> <div class=
=3D"ygroups-quoted"><br><br>--- In <a href=3D"mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com">=
neat@yahoogroups.com</a>, <colin.green1@...> wrote:<br><br><div>Hi al=
l,<br>
<br>
I'm starting to think about direction for the next SharpNEAT<br=
>
iteration. There's been a lot of talk recently about novelty search<br>
v=
ersus objective search, and maybe mixtures of the two. I myself<br>
talked =
about how in the natural world organisms are separated in both<br>
behaviou=
ral space (i.e. novel behaviour is less likely to compete for<br>
the same =
resources as existing behaviours) but also geographical<br>
space, and I th=
ink that geographical space is a key factor that is<br>
missing from NEAT b=
ased search currently, and possibly EC as a whole,<br>
with the caveat ther=
e may be other research groups with work in that<br>
area that I'm unaware =
of.<br>
<br>
My current plan is to focus on this geographical space idea fo=
r this<br>
iteration because it is the simplest to implement. Dealing with<=
br>
behavioural space is potentially more complicated because how to<br>
co=
mpare behaviour varies across problem domains and how you identify<br>
the =
key factors to compare is probably a non-trivial problem. I want<br>
to try=
 and tackle this at some point, but I'm also keen to explore the<br>
geo-sp=
ace idea.<br>
<br>
What does this all mean in practical terms?<br>
<br>
Sha=
rpNEAT is a kit of parts that allows you to swap in replacement<br>
parts s=
uch as an alternative genetic representation and/or associated<br>
genetic =
operators (recombination, mutation, etc) with minimal impact<br>
on other p=
arts in the kit (in principle anyway). I'm proposing to<br>
provide an alte=
rnative evolution algorithm class that replaces NEAT's<br>
genome based spe=
ciation (which clusters genomes into K clusters in<br>
genetic space), with=
 a geographical space alternative (I'll call it<br>
geo-space for short).<b=
r>
<br>
The idea is that we have some cartesian/euclidean space (probably a=
<br>
square 2D space initially to keep the code simple, but 3D or 'globe'<b=
r>
space (2-sphere) are reasonable alternatives). The seed genomes are<br>
=
each assigned a random coord in the geo-space and this will be fixed<br>
fo=
r the life of that genome. So we are basically adding a physical<br>
attrib=
ute to the genome such that our population members are probably<br>
better =
referred to as organisms (or agents or population members).<br>
I'll use 'a=
gent' because it's easier to type :)<br>
<br>
Agent fitness is now adjusted=
 by population density at the agent's<br>
geo-location, this allows really =
bad agents to survive so long as they<br>
are in a sparse region of geo-spa=
ce, thus allowing for some diversity<br>
of the genome pool.<br>
<br>
Repro=
duction - I haven't put much thought into this but the two<br>
options I se=
e are to create offspring agents near to their parent(s)<br>
versus randoml=
y scattered. Probably some 'dispersion' variable will<br>
define the amount=
 of scattering with 0 being atop of the parent (or<br>
between the two?) an=
d 1 being totally random. (Question: Is e.g. seed<br>
scattering in nature =
gaussian?). Clearly if agent's are spawned near<br>
their parent's we would=
 expect to see clusters of agent's with similar<br>
behaviour, and that clu=
stering will increase population density and<br>
therefore lower the fitnes=
s of agent's in that cluster. So there is a<br>
form of fitness sharing goi=
ng on, but as I say, I haven't really<br>
thought through the implications =
and dynamics of that. But it would be<br>
interesting to set up, play with =
and observe what happens.<br>
<br>
Factoring in behavioural space considera=
tions should be possible at a<br>
later date, e.g. fitness at a geo-locatio=
n is not adjusted down if an<br>
agent has novel behaviour compared to othe=
r agent's at that<br>
geo-location.<br>
<br>
As per usual - any thoughts an=
d feedback are welcome.<br>
<br>
Colin</div></div><div><br class=3D"webkit-=
block-placeholder"></div>
